column11: Review Text
Very big tree that you cannot see else ware in Sri Lanka (West or south) . Circumference -21.10 m and Height -10.50 m. well reserved and you can park the vehicle next to it
This is must visit place if you travel around. it's kind of special thing you can't see mostly. Take pictures, but don't spoil around.
In a fairly degraded environment on the island of Mannar, the baobabs are enormous survivors. What trees!!! Respect ...
This is the only tree here. Its a popular tourist spot. This tree very old. This tree is supposed to have been brought here by traders from Africa.

It is said that this tree was born by chance from a seed of imported goods centuries ago and, this be true or not, it‚Äôs a really impressing plant to admire. The trunk is huge, so are the branches and its bark is extremely interesting to touch and see. If you love plants, it‚Äôs a must!
Something you should see once in a lifetime. Not much things to see. But just to take a picture with huge tree

If you are traveling mannar i suggest everyone should visit this place to look at this giant tree.. and we were lucky that we met an amazing person who told us the story behind this tree.. I hope you too will get that chance if you visit this place.
You are not going to Mannar for this tree,but if you are in Mannar it is a ‚Äúmust‚Äù to see this wonderful Baobab..
Just a short distance from town, this tree has to be seen to be believed, it is huge.  Very low key, be careful not to miss it as you wander down the road

column8: A magnificent tree that is uncommon to this part of the world
column11: Out of the thirty odd Baobabs in Mannar the tree at Pallimunai is supposed to be the largest and with a known age of around 700 years. It is a fascinating tree with so much of horizontal growth that has occurred over centuries making it almost 21 meters in girth. The bark gives the appearance of stacked layers of burnt pan cakes. This tree species which hail from Africa and believed to have been introduced to Mannar by ancient traders has become a significant proof to the flourishing naval port in the area which had been patronised by foreign travellers  and traders in the ancient times.
Its really huge and of course we recommend everyone who travels through to pay a visit this huge tree.
This tree is said to be 900 years old.  Baobab tree is unique as the formation is as if the roots are upwards and above ground !
A huge baobab tree. Only few is found in Sri Lanka and this is one of them. Nothing much to do here just have a glimpse of the tree and go.

This is the oldest Baobab tree in Sri Lanka believed to around 740 years old, which are origin to Africa , Madagascar and Australia. This is one of the major tourist attractions in the area today and also known as the bottle tree since trunk of this tree can hold up to 12,000 litres of water.
We were recommended to go there and if you look at it in it's own merit it really is an amazing tree üòè. Not sure if it means much to everyone
it's a famous place in Mannar, although there's nothing much special about it. it's just a huge tree brought by Dutch to feed their horses, the story says...
Will enjoy the tree place and the tree was very admiring and the history of the tree was being more from the past visit you will like that
A sight to see! This tree is said to be the oldest and is easily accessible. The are are 5 or 6 more baobab  trees along the Talaimannar road

A lonely tree standing proud and tall not far from the town center. Faded boards that don't tell much at all about this lonely and old giant. One of those things to tick off on your list if you have 15 to 30 mins to spare.
Worth a trip there to see this amazing tree, there are others but this is the one to see.  Need to go with a big family to hold hands around it.

What a marvelous tree? The location is not very far from the town. It‚Äôs a must see. The tree is not that tall, but has a huge fat trunk. Legend says it‚Äôs not a native tree, but long time ago Arabian traders had brought these to feed camels.
There were very few tourists. This did have an interesting history to it. It is just about 1 km or less from the town.
Without the story behind the tree this wouldn't be so interesting.  There are only 2 baobab trees in the country, both brought here by a sailor

The tree is there, roadside, not with the attention of many and there's a name board next to it. A few local youths were hanging around the tree. They were the only ones in the location at the time I visited (around 1pm) and they spoke only Tamil. So even they could have had the ability to explain a little bit of history, I knew only English and Sinhala. It's okay to go and visit because its a special tree. But do your homework before/after - read about it.
Impresive, is a baobab tree bringed by the arabs centuries ago. I thought that these trees where dry but this one is huge and green. There is another group of 4- 5 outside mannar city
This is the only Baobab tree here.A tourist attraction here.The surrounding area is dirty.There is a Christian statue and a box for collection in front of the tree.
The Baobab Tree is well maintained and presentable but the signage needs to be updated so visitors can read the facts and figures.
You need to see this tree when you visit to Mannar. its in the city limit after the bridge. Very wide tree hope this is one of the largest trees in South Asia.

Gladely, it was not a detour for us going there. We had sometime going back from kitesurf in Mannar Island so we stop by. Nothing worth the visit if you're for away. It's a large but not high baobab with many publicities around.

heading Add to dictionary from Manner to see it. it's bit difficult to find a way reading boards thoug all written in tamil. so we asked from a police officer & he explain us to the road. & we had to pass small by roads too. from Dutch fort to bio-bab tree it may take 10 mints. so much hot & sunny day. no place to eat except a small shop in front of the tree. we ask him shall we eat inside the shop. that boy said ok. so we ordered lemon juice with our home made rice & curry which brought frome home. he offered original tasty juice with less sugar. that boy Is a nice guy. that shop offers many foods like short eats , burgers etc.. don't know how to made it. 1st we should order & then he prepared it. there a small toilet also behind the shop. thatDelete repeated word the only place we can find a place. so much rural area. they don't understand Sinhala. can mange bit English. feel like we are in india Chennai. bio bab tree is surrounding a small wall. so we can only see it from out side. that's good. if not it will not protect. as one of the rear tree in the world we should protect it.

This is only 500m away from the mannar city center and very easy to find. It's a very old bush type of a tree. Not that tall but with a huge circumference. There are other similar type of trees in mannar but not this big. It's worth seen this as it is a unique floral type.
visited this spot.  such shade it gives to every one.  A statue of St. Lucia is erected under the tree.  a place you everyone should visit.

made the effort to grab a tuktuk to take me out to see this majestic 700 year old beauty, and was so pleased i did. With a trunk circumference of over 20 metres and 7 metres high it is a sight to behold. Very spectacular to see, a tree that would have a thousand stories to share about all the people that have walked past, touched it, sat under and watched it grow over 7 centuries.. an amazing specimen with a lot of character, and amazing that its still intact given the devastation and destruction that's gone on all around it... a beautiful, sacred tree.
Supposed to have come through to Sri Lanka from Africa through the Muslim traders and it still stands tall in the city of Mannar as a place of interest.

Biobab tree in Mannar This is an African origin tree which is believed to be planted by Arabian sailors around 1470. It is 19.15 meters in circumference and 7.5 meters in height. This is one of the largest (if not the largest) trees in Asia. It is just about 1.5 km from Mannar city
The origin of this tree is Africa. You find plenty of Baobab trees in Mannar.  It attracts the attention of the travellers due to its shape.

Biggest tree in Mannar. There are many baobabs in Talaimannar road. It is couple of kilometers from Mannar town (Know as Pallimunai). Area is residential and may be unclean close to the tree with stray dogs and cows roaming around. Reminder of the arab connections for centuries in this part of Sri Lanka

This is the biggest tree I've ever seen. Too bad that it is in the city and surrounding by concrete (as other baobabs in neighborhood). There are more baobabs along the road to the end of island. Also good to see.
its rare to see an African tree in sri lanka. its a huge tree but small comparing to baobabs in Africa but its still huge..

We went via mannar to jaffna. The ride was really unique as via mannar it is a less taken road to jaffna and bio bab also you can make a stop to see. Maybe about a 1km divert from the main road. The tree is massive and has been there since 1700s and one f d largest barks. Its a pity some info on the board are missing. For me, if was unique, massive and also represens some darkness in the history.
An amazing attraction in Mannar is of this fascinating tree the Baobab tree, of which there are very few i Sri Lanka . well worth visiting Manner for.

It is very interesting to see such a giant of a tree and it's great this tree could be seen in Sri Lanka, when it's home is in the African Continent. It also gives a good idea of the interventions travellers made to bio diversity.
There are many more Baobab trees on the island. Many can be spotted off the Medawachchiya/ Talaimannar road

There are two huge Baobab Trees in Sri Lanka, one is here and the other in Delft Island, Jaffna. They are big trees as is the case with this species and it has a history attached to it. It's right by the road and seen on Google Maps, there isn't much to see in Mannar so every sight is counted by tourists. We went to Mannar to see a chunk of Sri Lankan life we usually don't see, untouched. Mannar was a good example :)

Since you're in Mannar, it would be remiss not to stop by and have a look at this tree. The setting is in a lovely, bustling square where ladies in sarees cycle past and children from the school wave and say hello. The tree is doing well for its age and it is impressive to see its size. Walk north to see fish drying in the sun and walk south to see the market and fort.

Some people call this the "Elephant tree" simply due to the fact that the bark of it has similarities to elephant skin. It is said that this tree was brought to the country by Arabic traders and its more than 700 years old. This is the most popular out of the very few Baobabs in Sri Lanka. Well worth visiting if you happen to be around Mannar.
Only tree can be seen in sri lanka other than in delft island as per my knowledge....its very much differ with our own trees...
This is planted tree (not native) and having old history. This is treated as one of the big tree in Sri Lanka.

If you are in Mannar then the visit is well worth. There's no info about the tree at the site, so if you want to know more you have to read up about it. This particular tree is supposedly the oldest and the largest baobab in Sri Lanka. This tree was calculated 723 years old in the 2003 study. The circumference of the tree is is 19.5 meters and its 7.5 meters tall.
This tree looks as it is upside down. Worth seeing the tree. Not far from the Mannar town. One has to go in the day time as there is no proper illumination.
A fine sight. Reputedly the largest in Asia. Non-native and probably planted by Arab traders c.540 years ago!
This is a historic value. Only few of those trees are found in this region and this could be among the oldest in Asian region.
As far as tree's go this is one cool tree. It's know to be the shortest tree with the widest circumference. Supposed to have been brought by the arabs way back when.
Approximately 800 years old tree. Located near Mannar town. Need to see this unique tree. Although to protect the tree barrier has been built most people tends to climb the tree to take photographs.

The #Baobab Tree is accessible by road and waling from the main town. Is is just one kilometre away. One landmark for seeking directions is asking where the "Food City Supermarket" is. the tree sits a few metres from there. It is well preserved. Ideal time to visit may be morning or after 3 pm, when light is very kind for good photos.

Very easy to find, it's not down a small side street and all locals are happy to point you in the direction of the tree. There isn't much to do at the tree but there is a small shop for refreshments and it's a nice thing to visit if you have made the effort to go to Mannar. We talked to a group of Sri Lankan people visiting the tree, they were very nice and made the experience more memorable
I actually don't remember the exact route to this place but however it's in the town like you don't need to be walking far I have a picture of myself with the tree.
Not a lot else to say, it's a pretty funky tree if you're into that...I am so I enjoyed it, but it's just a tree at the end of the day so 3*s it is
It is a special place to have a visit in Sri Lanka. A lots of same kind of trees around Mannar town, but this tree is the largest.
And hence nice to see the Mannar ones too, next to the big Delft island one. Worth a small detour for us!
This tree has been planted by Arab Traders in the 16th century.The circumference of the tree trunk is 19.5meters and about 7meters high.

This baobab tree is the second Baobab Tree Im seeing in Sri Lanka. (One in Delft Island - Jaffna). This Baobab tree believed to be 700 years old. Like 7m high and more than 15m large. Its in a village called Pallimunai a very close location from the city centre. Intresting to see..

We found the time to visit this Baobab tree while we were in Mannar. Interesting to know that its beleived to have been brought to Sri Lanka by the arabs and planted in the 1600's. The trunk of the tree is massive! Truely wuerd looking in this country.

Almost impossible to imagine the age of this tree. He is so large that it a challenge to take a picture. When we visited it, there were a whole bunch of cameleons at the branches which was extra nice.

This is one of the places of interests in Mannar. The baobabs in Sri Lanka is believed to have been brought by Arabian Traders. According to a study done in 2003, there are about 40 Baobab Trees surviving in Sri Lanka, out of which 34 has been identified and measured in Mannar. Most of the trees were calculated to be 300-400 years old. The oldest and the largest baobab is at Pallimunei which is said to be about 800 years old. This tree was calculated 723 years old in the 2003 study. The circumference of the tree is is 19.5 meters and its 7.5 meters tall.

This is a very close-by attraction just 1km away from Mannar Town. Do not forget to go to this place if you visit Mannar town. I visited Mannar fort , BioBab tree, Several Hindu shrines and Buddhist Temple close by. i saw a similar Bio bab tree in Delft Island- Jaffna and that one is bigger than this.

If you are a Nature Lover, or even otherwise, you must make a visit to this extremely rare Giant plant located about 1.5 - 2km away from Mannar Town. There is a road in front of Mannar Dry Fish market, very close to Mannar Bridge, and you will have to travel a short distance on this road. The tree is located on your left side, near St. Lucia's Church when you travel from Mannar Town. The TRUNK of the plant is HUGE, may be 8-10 people on average are needed to make a circle around the trunk. You can imagine the size of the trunk of the plant. However, the plant is not so tall, may be 7-7.5m. The plant has a very long life time; according to a very poorly legible descriptive notice board, it was planted by Arab sailors and may be planted in 1477.

Mahatirtha is the ancient name for Mannar. It means great port.  Ancient coins and other items from east and west is found here.  Baobab tree is a historic tree providing evidence of international relations. I have seen two other trees on thalimannar road.
really nothing to write home about. there are similar but not as old, boab trees in the district. the approach road is not particularly good.
Nothing much to see but one must have a look at this tree at least once, so do drop by and take some pictures. Try not to climb on the tree and take pictures, etc.

An offbeat attraction, this ancient baobab tree was allegedly planted by Arab traders. It has a circumference of 19.5m and is believed to be over 700 years old. In Africa the baobab is sometimes called the upside-down tree (because its branches look like roots); locals in Mannar refer to it as the ali gaha (elephant tree) since its tough, gnarled bark resembles the skin of an elephant. It's 1.2km northeast of the town centre.
